item.title: San Diego County eases restrictions on ocean access, mandates face coverings

item.description: San Diego County officials Friday announced that restrictions limiting ocean access will be lifted, paving the way for cities across the region to reopen beaches as soon as Monday.
item.content:encoded: San Diego County officials Friday announced that restrictions limiting ocean access will be lifted, paving the way for cities across the region to reopen beaches as soon as Monday.

media:content.media:description: A lone surfer left the beach at Ocean Beach on Tuesday morning, March 24, 2020. San Diego Police and lifeguards were warning surfers to get out of the water because the beaches are closed.

Joseph Schlitz enters the Hollywood Premier Healthcare Center, which has seen 25 cases among staff and 29 among residents on Friday, April 24, 2020 in Hollywood, CA. item.title: This is what it will take for L.A. County to lift stay-at-home orders, officials say

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIFORNIA - MARCH 26: People sit on a hill overlooking Dodger Stadium on what was supposed to be Major League Baseball's opening day, now postponed due to the coronavirus, on March 26, 2020 in Los Angeles, California. The Los Angeles Dodgers were slated to play against the San Francisco Giants at the stadium today. Major League Baseball Commissioner Rob Manfred recently said the league is "probably not gonna be able to" play a full 162 game regular season due to the spread of COVID-19. (Photo by Mario Tama/Getty Images)

item.title: Chicano Park 50 years later: Coronavirus delays celebration but historic moment still matters

media:content.media:description: The murals are a showcase and a snapshot of Chicano art from the neighborhood activism of the late 1960s and early '70s.

item.title: Here is the latest list of Orange County communities with coronavirus cases

item.description: The number of Orange County's coronavirus infections increased to 1,845 Friday as health officials announced 33 new cases.

media:content.media:description: LAGUNA WOODS, CA -- SATURDAY, APRIL 4, 2020: Orange County Sheriff's deputies wear protective masks as they keep an eye on mostly Laguna Woods seniors protesting after learning nearby Ayers Hotel will be used to treat homeless COVID2019 patients in Laguna Woods, CA, where the median age is about 75.5 years old on April 4, 2020. "It takes a village to save a village," Coe said, "because we are the Laguna Woods Village." Orange County has signed a lease to use a Laguna Woods Hotel to house 19 homeless patients with coronavirus that some neighbors - mostly a retirement community - and city officials are opposing. The county is trying to meet Gov. Newsom's mandate to shelter homeless in motels and hotels in order to help combat spread of coronavirus. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Why face shields may be better coronavirus protection than masks alone

item.description: It's harder to touch your face if you have a plastic barrier on it, experts say.
item.content:encoded: It's harder to touch your face if you have a plastic barrier on it, experts say.

media:content.media:description: VICTORVILLE, CA - APRIL 22: Dr. Imran Siddiqui, is a medical director at Desert Valley Medical Group in Victorville. Siddiqui's days have been long and stressful since the COVID-19 pandemic began its deadly assault on California. Being a devout Muslim his faith as much as duty that will require him to rise early each morning for the month fasting Ramadan on coming Friday. Like thousands of other faithful first responders he will be waking before dawn for a breakfast, then going without food and water through the daylight hours of Ramadan, which ends May 23. Victorville, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Judge orders ICE to reduce number of immigrant detainees at California facility

item.description: ICE must reduce the population at the Adelanto processing facility to allow detainees to keep six feet apart amid the coronavirus outbreak.
item.content:encoded: ICE must reduce the population at the Adelanto processing facility to allow detainees to keep six feet apart amid the coronavirus outbreak.

media:content.media:description: A lawsuit claims some previously deported detainees have been denied a speedy determination of their immigration status after they claimed a fear of persecution or torture if they are deported again. Above, detainees at the government's Adelanto, Calif., facility last fall.
media:content.media:credit: Cheryl A. Guerrero / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Why are the dead getting coronavirus stimulus checks?
item.dc:creator: Cindy Carcamo
item.description: Mary Nakamura was among the first to receive a $1,200 coronavirus stimulus check from the IRS. But she's been dead for more than a year.
item.content:encoded: Mary Nakamura was among the first to receive a $1,200 coronavirus stimulus check from the IRS. But she's been dead for more than a year.

media:content.media:description: SANTA ANA, CA -- TUESDAY, APRIL 21, 2020: Mason Nakamura holds a photo of himself with his late mother, Mary Nakamura, at his home in Santa Ana, CA, on April 21, 2020. Mary Nakamura received her stimulus payment on April 15. There's just one problem, she's deceased. The 96-year-old died about a year ago but her son Mason Nakamura, who handles her estate account, said his mother received a $1200 check. He wants to give that money back to the IRS, saying it doesn't make sense. Nakamura's mother is likely one of thousands who are deceased but received payments anyway. IRS experts said it's actually lawful for the dead to get stimulus payments and that it's not an error. The priority was put on getting payments out as quickly as possible and weeding out the dead would have likely delayed the process by weeks, if not months. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

item.title: California stay-at-home faces its biggest test: A heat wave driving people to the beach

Newsom at the closed Huntington Beach pier in Huntington Beach, CA, on April 22, 2020. The Orange County officials have been debating whether to close beaches and trailheads during an upcoming heat wave after coastal residents raised concerns about out-of-towners descending on their communities in droves. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: How to dress to save your life: L.A. Times photojournalists take on a whole new danger

item.content:encoded: Masks, gloves and protective clothing all help protect photographers out on the streets.

media:content.media:description: Marcus Yam Hereʼs an image of me suiting up before entering a hospital ward with a patient recovering from COVID-19 at UC San Diego Health. As photojournalists, we are often on the move, covering news around the world ­– foreign conflicts, humanitarian crises, mass migrations and social issues ­– that put our readers on the frontline of struggle and intimacy.

item.title: Hydraulic failure caused military jet to crash into warehouse, report says
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: A report says a loss of hydraulic pressure prevented a pilot from controlling an F-16 jet that crashed into a warehouse last year just outside March Air Reserve Base.
item.content:encoded: A report says a loss of hydraulic pressure prevented a pilot from controlling an F-16 jet that crashed into a warehouse last year just outside March Air Reserve Base.

media:content.media:description: This photo taken from video provided by KABC-TV shows where an F-16 fighter jet crashed into a warehouse just outside March Air Reserve Base in Riverside, Calif., Thursday afternoon, May 16, 2019. Maj. Perry Covington, director of public affairs at the base, says the pilot ejected before the crash and was not hurt and there are no immediate reports of injuries on the ground. (KABC-TV via AP)

item.title: Federal judge blocks California's ammunition purchase law
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: U.S. District Judge Roger Benitez of San Diego ruled in favor of the California Rifle & Pistol Assn., which asked him to stop the checks and related restrictions on ammo sales.
item.content:encoded: U.S. District Judge Roger Benitez of San Diego ruled in favor of the California Rifle & Pistol Assn., which asked him to stop the checks and related restrictions on ammo sales.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this June 11, 2019, file photo, Chris Puehse, owner of Foothill Ammo, displays .45-caliber ammunition for sale at his store in Shingle Springs, Calif. A federal judge on Thursday, April 23, 2020, blocked a California law requiring background checks for people buying ammunition, ruling the restrictions violate the constitutional right to bear arms. U.S. District Judge Roger Benitez of San Diego ruled in favor of the California Rifle & Pistol Association, which asked him to stop the checks and related restrictions on ammo sales. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, File)

item.title: Coronavirus deaths at 36 in Orange County as infection count tops 1,800
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: Health officials also announced 78 new coronavirus infections Thursday — the highest single-day total in a week — bringing the region's number of COVID-19 cases to 1,827.
item.content:encoded: Health officials also announced 78 new coronavirus infections Thursday — the highest single-day total in a week — bringing the region's number of COVID-19 cases to 1,827.

media:content.media:description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, CA -- WEDNESDAY, APRIL 22, 2020: Exterior view of Huntington Valley Healthcare Center in Huntington Beach, CA, on April 22, 2020. Two patients at the Orange County nursing home died this week from COVID-19 as a coronavirus outbreak at the facility has sickened half its residents and several staff members. Thus far, 48 other patients and 24 healthcare staff members at Huntington Valley Healthcare Center in Huntington Beach, have tested positive for the coronavirus, according to a news release from the company. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

Brodard's is one of Orange County's most famous Vietnamese Restaurants and is still doing take-out orders since the coronavirus shutdown many businesses. All employees wear safety masks and gloves and customers are required to wear a mask, but some do not comply. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

Jackson attended the Black Summit of the National Brotherhood of Skiers annual ski trip in late February, early March. Upon his return home he fell ill and died. (Jason Armond / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Suppliers cash in as California taxpayers hit with wildly inflated prices for masks

item.content:encoded: California is paying more than 300% above list prices for some coronavirus masks, state data show.

The vigil is organized by the California Nurses Association and National Nurses United unions. (Robert Gauthier / Los Angeles Times)

item.content:encoded: New information emerging in the past week in California paints a very different picture of the spread of novel coronavirus than the one suggested by the first, official version.

The Coroner's office has tripled its storage space to 1,500 to be ready for a possible Covid 19 pandemic surge in fatalities at the coroner's office on Wednesday, April 15, 2020 in LOS ANGELES, CA. (Robert Gauthier / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 'We aren't the dumping ground': Homeless people fleeing coronavirus meet NIMBY resistance
item.dc:creator: Doug Smith, Liam Dillon, Benjamin Oreskes
item.description: Lodging protests or threatening to sue hotel owners, some California cities and residents fight plans to house homeless people during the pandemic.
item.content:encoded: Lodging protests or threatening to sue hotel owners, some California cities and residents fight plans to house homeless people during the pandemic.

media:content.media:description: LAGUNA HILLS, CA - APRIL 16: Protestor Karen Litfin of Laguna Hills, stands outside of the site of a former Comfort Inn on Thursday, April 16, 2020 in Laguna Hills, CA. The city of Laguna Hills has filed a lawsuit to block the countys plan to use the facility to house homeless people with coronavirus. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Still no timetable for reopening California as coronavirus deaths rise
item.dc:creator: Phil Willon, Melanie Mason, Marisa Gerber, Luke Money
item.description: Though the coronavirus outlook has improved slightly, Gov. Gavin Newsom said there was no timetable for reopening California. "There is no light switch," the governor said.
item.content:encoded: Though the coronavirus outlook has improved slightly, Gov. Gavin Newsom said there was no timetable for reopening California. "There is no light switch," the governor said.

media:content.media:description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, CA -- WEDNESDAY, APRIL 22, 2020: Denise Martinez, of Costa Mesa, kneels down in prayer in front of the closed Huntington Beach pier as she spreads her message of love, not the anarchy that she says some of the stay-at-home protesters want. "I'm out here praying for the city," Martinez said. "And to show an example of Christ, who is love. Our freedom doesn't come from a spirit of anarchy. Right now our main focus is loving each other at any cost. The lord says today that he hears the cries of his people and to trust him. Because love overcomes everything." Beach-goers enjoyed warm summer-like weather amid state and city social distancing regulations to stave off Coronavirus mandated by Gov. Newsom in Huntington Beach, CA, on April 22, 2020. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Skelton: Give Newsom credit. He's trying it all to fight coronavirus and California's economic collapse
item.dc:creator: George Skelton
item.description: The most high-profile and potentially productive thing Newsom has done is create a "Task Force on Business and Jobs Recovery" to help California recover from coronavirus-related economic fallout.
item.content:encoded: The most high-profile and potentially productive thing Newsom has done is create a "Task Force on Business and Jobs Recovery" to help California recover from coronavirus-related economic fallout.

media:content.media:description: In this photo taken Thursday, April 9, 2020, Gov. Gavin Newsom gives his coronavirus update at the the Governor's Office of Emergency Services in Rancho Cordova, Calif. California public health officials said Friday, April 10, 2020, that the spread of the coronavirus in the state might not be as high as expected. Newsom said he was already making detailed plans on how to re-open the state while still stressing the need for people to say at home and stay away from others. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli)

item.content:encoded: Amid concerns over whether such a move would hold up in court, the L.A. City Council voted down a stricter eviction moratorium Wednesday.

item.title: 2 men freed from jail by California coronavirus order rearrested
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: Two men who were released from jails in California because of the COVID-19 outbreak were rearrested and accused of committing crimes shortly after being freed, authorities said.
item.content:encoded: Two men who were released from jails in California because of the COVID-19 outbreak were rearrested and accused of committing crimes shortly after being freed, authorities said.

item.title: California pastors' request to allow in-person worship is denied by federal judge
item.dc:creator: Cindy Chang
item.description: Churches in Riverside and San Bernardino counties must continue to follow government orders banning in-person religious services to prevent the spread of the novel coronavirus, a judge ruled.
item.content:encoded: Churches in Riverside and San Bernardino counties must continue to follow government orders banning in-person religious services to prevent the spread of the novel coronavirus, a judge ruled.

media:content.media:description: SANTA ANA-CA-APRIL 12, 2020: Ashley Amon, 33, and her daughters Alysha, 2, and Alexandria, 4, who are currently homeless, attend a gathering with fellow worshippers in their cars in a parking lot in Santa Ana to worship in an Easter service by Rev. Robert A. Schuller on Sunday, April 12, 2020. Schuller is reviving a practice that launched his father to worldwide acclaim- the drive-in ministry. For the past four years, the younger Schuller has been preaching primarily on social media, providing daily sermons from his "church with no walls." The COVID-19 outbreak - and the loss of in-person fellowship - led him back to his roots. "People need a place to go to worship on Easter, " he said. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Christina House/Christina House/Christina House/Los Angeles Time

item.title: A healthy woman suddenly died. She was the first known coronavirus fatality in the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Matt Hamilton, Paige St. John
item.description: Patricia Dowd of San Jose, who died Feb. 6, was the first known COVID-19 fatality in the U.S.
item.content:encoded: Patricia Dowd of San Jose, who died Feb. 6, was the first known COVID-19 fatality in the U.S.

media:content.media:description: Santa Clara County Public Health Department Director Dr. Sara Cody speaks during a news conference in San Jose, Calif., on Friday, Feb. 28, 2020. Santa Clara County health officials confirmed a second case of unknown origin of the novel coronavirus. (Anda Chu/Bay Area News Group via AP)

item.title: As temperatures heat up in the Inland Empire and farther east, pools remain closed due to coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Brown
item.description: Although temperatures will reach the triple digits in areas of the Inland Empire this weekend, swimming pools and other water facilities will remain closed.
item.content:encoded: Although temperatures will reach the triple digits in areas of the Inland Empire this weekend, swimming pools and other water facilities will remain closed.

media:content.media:description: PALM SPRINGS, CALIFORNIA - APRIL 3, 2020: A Palm Springs resident finds the serenity of a closed golf course the perfect place for afternoon reading during the coronavirus pandemic at Tahquitz Creek Golf Resort on April 3, 2020 in Palm Springs. All the golf courses are closed in the desert communities. Declining to give his name, he said he's reading a novel by German philosopher Friedrich Nietzsche. Which seems very relevant during these times. Some of Nietzsche's famous quotes are, "To live is to suffer, to survive is to find meaning in the suffering," and "That which does not kill us makes us stronger." Also, "Without music, life would be a mistake."
media:content.media:credit: Gina Ferazzi/Gina Ferazzi/Gina Ferazzi/Los Angeles Times

Elena lives nearby and is walking to her job where she is the legal administrator at a law firm but her hours have been cut from 50 hours a week to 5 hours a week. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Pharmacy tech accused of stealing hydroxychloroquine
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: The man is accused of taking more than 700 tablets of hydroxychloroquine, an anti-malaria drug, along with the antibiotic azithromycin from Harbor-UCLA Medical Center.
item.content:encoded: The man is accused of taking more than 700 tablets of hydroxychloroquine, an anti-malaria drug, along with the antibiotic azithromycin from Harbor-UCLA Medical Center.

media:content.media:description: This Monday, April 6, 2020, photo shows an arrangement of hydroxychloroquine pills in Las Vegas. President Donald Trump and his administration kept up their out-sized promotion Monday of an malaria drug not yet officially approved for fighting the new coronavirus, even though scientists say more testing is needed before it's proven safe and effective against COVID-19. Trump trade adviser Peter Navarro championed hydroxychloroquine in television interviews a day after the president publicly put his faith in the medication to lessen the toll of the coronavirus pandemic. (AP Photo/John Locher)

item.title: Orange County reports its highest coronavirus hospitalization count

item.content:encoded: Orange County heath officials confirmed 67 new coronavirus cases Wednesday, bringing the total to 1,753, and one additional death, for a toll of 34.

item.title: Newsom says California shutdown must continue, but surge in testing will help
item.dc:creator: Phil Willon, Taryn Luna
item.description: California Gov. Gavin Newsom announces efforts to expand coronavirus testing as a key factor in determining when to ease stay-at-home orders.
item.content:encoded: California Gov. Gavin Newsom announces efforts to expand coronavirus testing as a key factor in determining when to ease stay-at-home orders.

media:content.media:description: California Gov. Gavin Newsom announced California saw its first daily decrease in intensive care hospitalizations during the coronavirus outbreak, during his daily news briefing at the Governor's Office of Emergency Services in Rancho Cordova, Calif. Thursday, April 9, 2020. Newsom announced that California saw its first daily decrease in intensive care hospitalizations during the coronavirus outbreak, a key indicator of how many health care workers and medical supplies are needed. He went on to say the state's hospitals have thousands of ventilators available should the number of the sickest patients suddenly surge. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, Pool)

item.title: California's largest workers' comp insurer just made it easier to file COVID-19 claims
item.dc:creator: Kim Christensen, Anita Chabria
item.description: California's largest workers' compensation insurer has lifted a requirement that essential workers with COVID-19 prove they contracted the virus on the job.
item.content:encoded: California's largest workers' compensation insurer has lifted a requirement that essential workers with COVID-19 prove they contracted the virus on the job.

media:content.media:description: Members of the Los Angeles Fire Department conduct COVID-19 testing on Skid Row in Los Angeles on Tuesday.

item.title: Tickets for speeding in excess of 100 mph surge 87% amid coronavirus shutdown, CHP says
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: California shutdown: CHP sees 87% increase in tickets for drivers going more than 100 mph amid coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: California shutdown: CHP sees 87% increase in tickets for drivers going more than 100 mph amid coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA, WEDNESDAY MARCH 25, 2020 - Traffic is light as rush hour looms at the intersection of the 110 and the 105 freeways. (Robert Gauthier/Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Robert Gauthier/Robert Gauthier/Robert Gauthier/Robert Gauthier/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Following coronavirus closure, Mt. Baldy ski resort reopening in limited capacity
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: The plan to reopen the San Bernardino County ski destination in a limited capacity marks the latest effort to allow limited recreation amid the coronavirus outbreak.
item.content:encoded: The plan to reopen the San Bernardino County ski destination in a limited capacity marks the latest effort to allow limited recreation amid the coronavirus outbreak.

media:content.media:description: MT. BALDY, CALIF. -- SATURDAY, JANUARY 18, 2020: A skiers rides a lift among large pines at Mt. Baldy ski resort in Mt. Baldy, Calif., on Jan. 18, 2020. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Kristin Smart cold case: New warrant served at San Pedro home of former classmate
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: Investigators have served a search warrant at the home of a former Cal Poly San Luis Obispo classmate of Kristin Smart, who disappeared 24 years ago.
item.content:encoded: Investigators have served a search warrant at the home of a former Cal Poly San Luis Obispo classmate of Kristin Smart, who disappeared 24 years ago.

media:content.media:description: SAN PEDRO, CALIFORNIA—FEB. 5, 2020—Sheriff deputies search the home of a suspect Paul Flores in the case of missing student Kristin Smart who vanished from Cal Poly San Luis Obispo nearly 24 years ago. The suspect was released after a thorough check of his home and vehicles at 937 West Upland in San Pedro, California on Feb. 5, 2020. (Carolyn Cole/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: These eerie photos show LAX as a ghost town. Passenger air travel is down more than 90%
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: Photos from LAX, where a handful of passengers still pass through the terminals, with air traffic nationwide down due to the coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: Photos from LAX, where a handful of passengers still pass through the terminals, with air traffic nationwide down due to the coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA -- APRIL 21: A lone passenger wearing personal protective equipment wonders through an empty Tom Bradley International Terminal as the coronavirus outbreak has brought passenger traffic to a near halt with travel down 95% at LosAngeles International Airport, the nation's second busiest, on Tuesday, April 21, 2020, in Los Angeles, CA. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Street racers are taking over California roads emptied by coronavirus
item.dc:creator: James Queally, Richard Winton
item.description: California shutdown: Street racers are taking over road emptied by coronavirus, with fatal results
item.content:encoded: California shutdown: Street racers are taking over road emptied by coronavirus, with fatal results

media:content.media:description: Illegal Street racing activities on Ana Street in Compton on Apr. 13, 2015. One of the several illegal street racing locations racers raced.
media:content.media:credit: Lawrence K. Ho / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Tulare County demands action after coronavirus outbreak kills 15 at one nursing home
item.dc:creator: Melissa Gomez
item.description: The coronavirus outbreak at Redwood Springs Healthcare Center in Visalia accounts for more than half the reported cases in Tulare County.
item.content:encoded: The coronavirus outbreak at Redwood Springs Healthcare Center in Visalia accounts for more than half the reported cases in Tulare County.

media:content.media:description: The Redwood Springs Healthcare Center, a skilled nursing facility in Visalia, announced two healthcare staff members and six patients had tested positive for COVID-19.

item.title: Coronavirus slashing money immigrants send home by 20%, creating second economic crisis
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: Remittances will fall by 20%, from $554 billion in 2019 to an expected $445 billion this year, the World Bank warned.
item.content:encoded: Remittances will fall by 20%, from $554 billion in 2019 to an expected $445 billion this year, the World Bank warned.

media:content.media:description: Remittances to most Latin American countries have picked up again after slumping during the Great Recession. But money sent by Mexican immigrants to their homeland this year, an estimated $22 billion, remains 29% off its 2006 peak, the Pew Research Center reports Friday in a study of flows and trends over 13 years.

item.title: 'Second wave' of coronavirus could be far worse for California than the first, officials warn
item.dc:creator: Luke Money, Deborah Netburn, Matt Hamilton, Colleen Shalby, Paige St. John, Marisa Gerber
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom and others have said that the worst of the coronavirus may be yet to come and that lifting stay-at-home orders now could be disastrous.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Gavin Newsom and others have said that the worst of the coronavirus may be yet to come and that lifting stay-at-home orders now could be disastrous.

media:content.media:description: ##PATIENT PROVIDED VERBAL CONSENT TO HOSPITAL REPRESENTATIVES## CHULA VISTA, CALIF. -- FRIDAY, APRIL 10, 2020: RN Arnold Garcia collects a sample for a coronavirus test from Michael Weiss after he was admitted with possible COVID-19 symptoms at Sharp Chula Vista Medical Center in Chula Vista, Calif., on April 10, 2020. On the left, RN Shauna Stanfill supervises. (Marcus Yam / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Are homeless shelters 'a nasty experiment' during coronavirus? L.A. says no and opens more
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Oreskes, Doug Smith
item.description: Coronavirus outbreaks have hit many homeless shelters across the country. But L.A. is moving forward with a plan to open shelters in recreation centers.
item.content:encoded: Coronavirus outbreaks have hit many homeless shelters across the country. But L.A. is moving forward with a plan to open shelters in recreation centers.

media:content.media:description: WESTWOOD, CALIF. -- FRIDAY, MARCH 20, 2020: LA City parks and recreation staff along with volunteers from the Salvation Army set up cots for homeless at Westwood Recreation Center in Westwood, Calif., on March 20, 2020. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Brian van der Brug/Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: UC experts offer new ammunition against the SAT and ACT as an admissions requirement
item.dc:creator: Teresa Watanabe
item.description: Three University of California admissions experts slammed a faculty recommendation to keep the SAT and ACT for at least five years, giving ammunition to critics of the controversial exams who want to drop their requirement for admissions.
item.content:encoded: Three University of California admissions experts slammed a faculty recommendation to keep the SAT and ACT for at least five years, giving ammunition to critics of the controversial exams who want to drop their requirement for admissions.

media:content.media:description: A recent decision by the College Board to return the SAT's main test to two parts -- math and reading -- has sparked a debate among colleges about whether to require applicants to take an optional essay portion.

item.title: Orange County debates closing beaches as hot weather raises fears of out-of-town crowds
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: With the upcoming heat wave, Orange County worries out-of-towners will descend on beaches in droves, raising the risk of coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: With the upcoming heat wave, Orange County worries out-of-towners will descend on beaches in droves, raising the risk of coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, CALIF. -- THURSDAY, APRIL 2, 2020: Kylie Wortham, 18, of Huntington Beach, who was laid off when her entire company was closed due to Coronavirus social distancing rules, relaxes with a book in a hammock overlooking the beach in Huntington Beach Thursday, April 2, 2020. The pier, beach parking lots and most shops are closed due to state-mandated Coronavirus social distancing rules. The area is normally teeming with spring break visitors. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Zoos have little revenue but still must feed animals, who seem to miss their human audience
item.dc:creator: Susanne Rust
item.description: As people shelter in place amid the pandemic, zoos have lost ticket revenues needed for a major expense — feeding animals.
item.content:encoded: As people shelter in place amid the pandemic, zoos have lost ticket revenues needed for a major expense — feeding animals.

media:content.media:description: OAKLAND, CALIFORNIA-APRIL 20, 2020-Two mountain lions hang together in a hammock on April 20, 2020 at the Oakland Zoo. The arrived at the zoo as rescues. The Oakland Zoo is closed due to the coronavirus, leaving the zoo without ticket sales. The costs of operating the zoo is 2 million dollars per month. (Carolyn Cole / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Here are the latest numbers of coronavirus cases in L.A. County communities
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: Los Angeles County officials confirmed 1,400 more coronavirus cases, 880 of which came from a backlog. The death toll rises to 663.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County officials confirmed 1,400 more coronavirus cases, 880 of which came from a backlog. The death toll rises to 663.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA, TUESDAY, APRIL 21 - Downtown shines in the setting sun looking East from MacArthur Park during the Coronavirus pandemic. (Robert Gauthier / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: In rural California, children face isolation, hunger amid coronavirus school closures
item.dc:creator: Hailey Branson-Potts
item.description: Schools in rural parts of the state are struggling not only to teach but to reach students. Many lack internet access and rely on schools for food.
item.content:encoded: Schools in rural parts of the state are struggling not only to teach but to reach students. Many lack internet access and rely on schools for food.

media:content.media:description: Principal receives a thank you card.

item.title: Getting free internet is hard for poor students despite provider promises, survey finds
item.dc:creator: Howard Blume, Sonali Kohli, Paloma Esquivel
item.description: Low-income L.A. families are struggling to get students connected to the internet even with promises of help from phone and cable providers. A survey found 16% still unconnected.
item.content:encoded: Low-income L.A. families are struggling to get students connected to the internet even with promises of help from phone and cable providers. A survey found 16% still unconnected.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - APRIL 01, 2020 8-year-old 2nd grade student Paulina De Loza holds her computer issued at the Ellen Ochoa Learning Center in Cudahy while her Mother Yadire De Loza holds another computer for her 2 brothers also in LAUSD schools as some students in LAUSD are issued computers Wednesday morning April 1, 2020. The campuses are closed because of the coronavirus Covid 19, but 63 schools are being used to hand out computers. In addition, students are picking up computers and internet hotspots from schools as well as homework packets. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A.'s most crowded neighborhoods fear outbreaks: 'If one of us gets it, we are all going to get it'
item.dc:creator: Ben Poston, Tony Barboza, Ryan Menezes
item.description: Coronavirus: L.A.'s most crowded neighborhoods fear outbreaks: 'If one of us gets it, we are all going to get it'
item.content:encoded: Coronavirus: L.A.'s most crowded neighborhoods fear outbreaks: 'If one of us gets it, we are all going to get it'

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF. - APR. 18, 2020. Alvarado Street in the Westlake District of Los Angeles, which has the second highest population density in the city, with about 38,214 people per square mile. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column: The coronavirus pandemic has made one thing perfectly clear: It's time to split the country
item.dc:creator: Steve Lopez
item.description: After five weeks stuck at home watching cable news, I say it's time for California to secede.
item.content:encoded: After five weeks stuck at home watching cable news, I say it's time for California to secede.

media:content.media:description: Protesters from ReOpenNC fill Lane Street as they march calling on North Carolina Gov. Roy Cooper to ease COVID-19 restrictions due to economic concerns on Tuesday, April 21, 2020 in Raleigh, N.C. (Robert Willett/The News & Observer via AP)
